text: does the <https://hub.docker.com/r/digitalrebar/provision/> docker image include the portal software?
Hmm - not sure how to answer that.  The container has dr-provision that starts and redirects to the portal.
the Portal is a RackN commercial for hosted on-premise
Rackn maintains a version of the Portal for Open use in it's current form (eg <https://portal.rackn.io/> )
<@U9RB70BJ7> it's also worth noting that the UX runs from your browser.  Your browser is the bridge,  the endpoint does not send data to the saas.

ah ok, I think I understand.  so unless we're running the "on-prem" mode,  the browser loads the UX bits from <http://portal.rackn.io|portal.rackn.io>, then proceeds to manage the endpoint host it was originally redirected from.?
your browser then continues to act as a "bridge" between the Endpoint and the Portal
for any subsequent calls/actions (eg installing Content from the RackN Library, etc)

basic network requirements are as follows:
admin browser outbound port 443 for HTTPS to <http://portal.rackn.io|portal.rackn.io>
admin browser outbound to port 8092 (by default) for HTTPS API access to Endpoint
it allows the DRP Endpoint to operate in an air-gapped environment with an "enabled VPN access" to that Management network

which allows UX use of the hosted Portal 
for true on-prem only air-gapping - no VPN or Internet access - then RackN commercial Portal can be installed onsite
for reference, it's a cross origin resource sharing (CORS) approach where the UX contacts multiple host servers   <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-origin_resource_sharing>

attachments.title: Cross-origin resource sharing
attachments.text:
Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that allows restricted resources (e.g. fonts) on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the domain from which the first resource was served. A web page may freely embed cross-origin images, stylesheets, scripts, iframes, and videos. Certain "cross-domain" requests, notably Ajax requests, are forbidden by default by the same-origin security policy.
CORS defines a way in which a browser and server can interact to determine whether or not it is safe to allow the cross-origin request. It allows for more freedom and functionality than purely same-origin requests, but is more secure than simply allowing all cross-origin requests. The specification for CORS was originally published as a W3C Recommendation but that document is obsolete. The current actively-maintained specification that defines CORS is the Fetch Living Standard.
